MCKENNA HOUSE - TOM & EDIE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT TOM MCKENNA, a slightly weathered husband and father of t snaps awake at the sound of the scream and leaps out of b races to the door in the dark. INT. MCKENNA HOUSE - SARAH‘S ROOM SARAH MCKENNA - an adorable five year old girl - is sitti bolt upright in her bed, screaming. A light snaps on as Tom, wearing pajama bottoms and a wor look - comes racing in to save his daughter. He takes her in his arms.

dialogues.text: Hmnm. Shadow monsters. They look pretty scary. But they can’t really do anything. Especially when the lights are on. They're afraid of the light.

dialogues.text: You could say that.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: That sounds like a brilliant solution. Edie sits on the bed and hugs her daughter. Tom smiles an arm around his son, who pulls away, embarrassed. He is, a

dialogues.text: The McKenna‘s station wagon tools down the road towards t INT. McKENNA‘S STATION WAGON Edie‘s at the wheel. Tom sits next to her, looking out th Edie notices the half smile on his face.

dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: One minute you're this dumb kid, running around like an idiot, getting inte trouble, dreaming these impossible dreams, and then, all of a sudden, you're this grown-up sitting around worrying about whether or not your children are gonna be okay.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I remember reading a book in high school that had a bit about that. Something about how one moment summer vacation’s the longest stretch of time imaginable and an unhooked bra strap is as close to heaven as you can possibly imagine. The next, you‘re middle aged wondering where it all went.

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: Don‘t be in such a hurry. We’re not middle aged yet.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know.

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: t don’t feel like a real grown-up yet.

dialogues.speaker: TOM

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: Yup. Everyone does, eventually. Sooner or later, you're gonna wake up and find out you've turned into that cranky old guy who yeils out the window, “Keep that noise down, you gaddam kids!” ‘TOM God. Kill me before that happens, okay?

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: Oh, honey, I’11 have left you long before that. She smiles at him, and slows the car down. He leans towar they kiss. The kiss grows long and passionate - Edie is s happy. Tom’s hand slides inside the back of her shirt and towards her bra. She pulls away, laughing. EDIE (cont‘d) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You know, an unhooked bra is still pretty damn close to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: You're a nut. He smiles warmly at her. EDIE (cont'd) I‘1l be done early today. All I have is the Watson's will and Dave Ryan‘s tractor sale, Want me to come pick you up?

dialogues.speaker: EDIE

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY

dialogues.text: When I was growing up, we didn’t talk a lot about how to be a man. It was just something your daddy was supposed to pass on to you. The things my daddy passed on to me... Well, I guess it wasn’t enough. Sure, it helped me make it through that war, but nothing he taught me helped me know how to make it back home. Your momma did her best, Edie. She stood by me when she should have taken you and just gone, and I paid her back by treating her worse than a dog. They just opened the doors, and it was easier to go through them than close ‘em. If I’d loved her the way I should... If I'd loved you the way I should.... I don’t know. Edie looks shaken at this. dialogues.text: A corner restaurant in the middle of the city. Joey walks to it and leoks at the sign hanging outside. He walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nice boho kind of joint. College kids and young urban professionals enjoy vegetarian meals in a delicate, prett decor. A maitre'd approaches him. MAITRE'’D How many in your party, sir?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: What happened to Murph’s? MAITRE‘D Sir?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: This place used to be Murphy's Tavern. Christ, I mean, forever. Since the forties, at least.

dialogues.speaker: MAITRE'D
dialogues.text: Oh, Murphy's. They were shut down at least six years ago.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: For what? MAITRE’D They were serving minors. Joey shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, that figures. MAITRE’D Will you be having dinner, sir?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: No. I don’t think so. Thanks. He stops, then turns back. JOEY {cant’d) Track and Turf still around? MAITRE‘D That place on 45th? Yeah. I think so. Joey nods and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A real dive bar. A broken neon sign in the window reads "Track & Turf” backwards. A battered old bar in the middl few booths, a couple tables with mismatched old chairs. A decent sized, albeit ratty crowd fills the place. Joey walks in and looks around. He looks in the corner and see decrepit old slide bowling machine and smiles. He walks t the bar and sits. The bartender walks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Genny Cream. The bartender puts a bottle in front of Joey, who takes a long pull and looks around the place. He spots a MAN sitt in a booth in the back and gets up and walks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOEY (cont'd) Where’‘s Ruben?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Ruben? Shit. Ruben’s been dead for ten years, man. Joey nods and turns to walk away. MAN (cont‘d) The man is gone, but his tradition lives on.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Yeah? The man nods. Joey sits down across from him. JOEY (cont ’d) I'm looking to buy.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: You bought from Ruben?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Once. Long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: What you lookin’ for?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I don't know. Something in a semi- automatic. I need two of them. Major stopping nower. And ammo. Couple more items. I need to see what you’ve got. The man nods.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: You a cop?

dialogues.speaker: JCEY
dialogues.text: Do I look like a cop?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Shit. You look like a farmer on vacation. Joey smiles. 97.  98. EXT. TORRINO’S CHEESE SHOP ~ NIGHT Joey stands across the street, in the shadows, looking at old cheese shop. He pulls a gun out of his jacket, cocks and walks determinedly towards the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OLD MAN stands behind the counter, wrapping a large bl of cheese in wax paper with one hand. Except for him, the store is empty. The door slams open and Joey barrels in, gun in hand, fac grim. The Old Man flinches, but doesn't look up.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: You'd be Joey Behan.

dialogues.speaker: JORY
dialogues.text: T am. The Old Man continues wrapping, not making eye contact wi Joey.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: You're in the wrong place.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Where are they keeping Richie?

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: You know the old beach house?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: The one in Surf City? The Old Man nods. JOEY (cont'd) You got the address? The old man puts down the block of cheese, picks up a pen and writes the address down on a piece of brown paper. Jo notices that his other arm doesn’t seem to work. JOEY (cont'd) How many men there?

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Ain't more than five of them leit.

dialogues.speaker: SOEY
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: I just run the shop.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Torrino’s gone, you know.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: I know. Joey nods towards the man's dead arm.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: What happened to your arm? The Old Man turns to face Joey for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: You know, Joey. Joey’s jaw tightens. He takes the piece of paper and nods grimly, walks out of the shop. The Old Man goes back to h ‘cheese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waves crash on the beach as the sun peeks over the horizo Joey's truck is pulled over by the side of the road. INT. JOEY’S TRUCK Joey sits in the driver seat, sipping coffee from a “Worl Greatest Dad” mug. He's fully strapped ~ crisscrossing underarm holsters with guns. A huge knife in a strap-on holster sits next to him. He finishes the coffee, slips t strap on around his leg under his pants, and puts a jacke over the holsters. He gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B big old beach house sits at the edge of the dunes. It's seen better days. Three or four cars are parked at random angles in the driveway. A large man in a football jersey Thug #1 ~ stands by the front door, casually keeping an e out. Ke hears a slight scuffling noise and whirls, producing a out of nowhere. Nothing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He eases back just as Joey appears behind him, knife in h Joey whips a hand over the man’s mouth and slams the knif into his back again and again. Thug #1 sags to the ground doey watches him drop, blood staining his jacket. He turn the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUG #2 and #3 sit around a coffee table, drinking coffee guns sitting in front of them. Thug #2 reads a paper.

dialogues.speaker: THUG
dialogues.text: You ever read the funnies?

dialogues.speaker: THUG
dialogues.text: Not anymore. Nothing funny left.

dialogues.speaker: THUG
dialogues.text: Ain‘t that the goddam truth. I can’t believe how bad this Cathy shit is, Someone should strangle this bitch. The front door opens. THUG #2 (cont'd) Yo, Marvin. What’s up, You‘re supposed tow... They look up and see Joey standing there, a gun in each h The two men scramble for their guns, but Joey fires first Thug #2 goes down in a spray of blood. Thug #3 dives to the floor, knocking the table over. The coffee, cups, newspaper and guns crash to the floor and h scrambles for a gun. Joey moves quickly and leaps on the man’s back, slams his in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Where‘s Richie?

dialogues.speaker: THUG
dialogues.text: Downstairs. We got a basement. He's down there. Joey nods.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about this,

dialogues.speaker: THUG
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: INT, BASEMENT
dialogues.text: THUG #4 leans against a wall, gun in hand, waiting. The basement door slams open and something crashes down. Thug whips out from behind the wall blasting. He steps out to that he‘s shot the hell out of an old armchair.

dialogues.speaker: THUG
dialogues.text: Shit. Joey pops up in the basement door and blasts away, nailin the Thug. Joey cautiously creeps down the stairs, ready for anythin He‘s stained with the blood of the men he's killed. He steps down into the dark basement and looks around. Hi switch on the wall and the lights go on. The basement is empty. He hears a sound, and looks ~ across the room is a door leading into a smaller area. Joey cautiously steps towards it.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Alright. Whoever’s in there... Come on out. A long beat. Then....

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Joey?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Richie? MAN‘S VOICE (0.S.} Joey! Help me. I'm all alone in here, Joey cautiously approaches the door. Takes a deep breath pushes it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICHIE, a gcod looking man the same age as Joey, sits on chair in the middle of the room, his hands tied behind hi back. Joey steps in, gun in hand.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Jesus. Richie. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Joey! Oh my God. Joey!

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: How many here?

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: What? Those guys? Just four.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I was expecting five.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: I dunno. I only know four. Jesus, Joey! You came! Untie met! Joey holsters his guns and walks over to Richie and leans down. Except Richie‘s hands aren't tied. Richie whips out a gun and points it at Joey’s head. Joey freezes. RICHIE (cont'd) Oh, yeah. There were five. Richie stands up, gun still pointed. RICHTE (cont‘d) I knew you'd come, Didn‘t think you'd make it this far, though. I was hoping for a little less bloodshed, Joey. Jesus, you're good with the killing, aren’t you? Joey glares at him. RICHIE (cont’d} Why do you think that is? You think it's genetic? You think your old man was some kind of killer? Or is it just chance?

dialogues.speaker: JORY
dialogues.text: They didn’t track you down,

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Oh, hell no. i've always been here, Joey. Right here where you left me.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: What happened? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RICHTE
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea what it takes to talk one of these wiseguy fucks out of killing you? Joey shakes his head. RICHIE (cont'd) I told him the whole story, man. I told him how you talked me out of going away to school so I could help you kill him. He liked that loyalty thing, you know? He liked that I’d give up what I wanted for a friend, Joey. Or Tom. You prefer Tom? You’re starting to look like a Tom, you know? Yeah, well, anyway, after a while, he started letting me do some work for him. Made me do the dirtiest goddam jobs he had. Lots of fun shit. I got good at it, too. You wouldn't believe how easy it is to just slide into Bad. Oh, hell. Yeah, you would. Joey doesn’t respond. RICHIE (cont‘d) You got nothing to say? Huh? You just gonna sit there and listen? He steps forward and smacks Joey in the head with the but the gun, Joey's head snaps back, but he doesn’t say anyth RICHIE (cont'd) Hey! I’m talkin’ here! He smacks him again, this time drawing blood. Joey wipes blood from his forehead and responds quietly and evenly.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I‘m listening.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. You better. You fuckin’ better. He steps back and composes himself a beat. RICHIE (cont'd) All that really matters is that it got to the point where Torrino actually trusted me, and when you bumped the old man, that left me in charge of what was left of his shit. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: RICHIE (cont'd) Course, now you‘ve taken care of that, so I’m gonna have to go work for the New York guys, start over at the bottom. Like I don’t owe you for enough as it is. Goddam you, Joey. I could have had a real life. I was going to go to fucking college, man. Guys like us, how many of us make it that far? You did this, Joey. you did this to my life. Joey steps toward Richie.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I guess I kinda knew some of that. They just found you out of the blue, the same time they found me? Didn’t make sense.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Then why’d you come back?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I came here to save you.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: You missed your chance a long time ago. e Joey steps closer. Richie raises the gun, pointing it a head.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: X thought I could live with what I‘d done to you, Richie. In the end, I couldn't. I wanted to believe I could save you, but I guess this'll have to do. He sticks his forehead up against the barrel of Richie’s JCEY (cont'd) You do what you have to.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: I want you to beg for me.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Not gonna happen. Just end it.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Alright. Then beg for your family.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: My family...?

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: I seen your wife on TV. She's got a real bloom to her. I think I'11 fuck her before I kill her. How about that? You willing to beg for that? Without warning, Joey whips his head to the left, causing Richie’s gun to slide forward, past his head. Richie stag forward, and grunts in surprise. The gun goes off, but Jo knocks it out of his hand with his free hand. Richie slowly looks down and sees Joey‘s other hand - it’ wrapped around the knife sticking into Richie’s belly. Ri staggers back, clutching the knife, blood gushing. Joey calmly pulls out one of his guns and points it at Richie.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I‘m willing to kill for that, Richie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey walks towards the beach, battered and blood soaked. walks down to the edge of the water and hurls his revolve as far as they'll go. We takes the bloody knife out of it holster and throws it after them. He tears off the knife holster and the underarm holsters and throws them into th sea as well. He rips his bloody shirt off and throws it in after the weapons, then falls to the sand and sits, staring out as sun rises over the horizon, water lapping closer and clos to his feet. He sits a long, long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom’s pickup pulls up in front of the house. Tom gets out looks at the house, sees the station wagon parked in fron The field has been cleaned up, all remnants of the propan tank are gone. Tom walks to the front door and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty. Tom hears a sound in another room, and heads for t kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edie sits at the head of the table, dishing out dinner to Jack and Sarah. Jack and Sarah look up when he walks in, go back to their meals. Edie doesn't look up. Tom stands the doorway a long beat, then sits in his chair. A long beat as the family eats. Tom looks around at his family, who don’t return his look, He closes his eyes and fights back the tears. Sarah looks around the table, at h mother and brother, then her father. She’s thinking hard. Sarah gets up and walks over to the counter and picks up plate and some silverware and puts them in front of her father, her face very straight. Tom looks at her, his eye wet, and smiles. She shoots him an uncertain smile, then back to her seat. Jack, chewing his dinner, looks at the serving plate in t middle of the table. He swallows, then pushes the plate o in front of his father, not making eye contact. Tom smile gratitude. He looks across the table at Edie, who stares intently at food in front of her. After a lang beat, she looks up at her husband, her face impassive. He looks back, no idea what she‘s thinking, no idea what the future holds. But he sees something in her eyes, and for now, that’s enough. There's hope.
